thread.title: Avian flu fears grow amid waterfowl spread, presumptive human case in Wisconsin
thread.title_full: Avian flu fears grow amid waterfowl spread, presumptive human case in Wisconsin

author: Marlo Lundak, FOX 11 News
title: Avian flu fears grow amid waterfowl spread, presumptive human case in Wisconsin
text:
GREEN BAY (WLUK) -- A presumptive human case of bird flu [has been recorded in Wisconsin](https://fox11online.com/news/state/wisconsin-reports-first-presumptive-human-case-of-bird-flu-in-barron-county-avian-sickness-poultry-cdc-hygiene-birds-wild-domestic-contagious-virus#) and it's causing changes in how officials think we should engage with our winged friends.
Bird flu, also known as avian flu, is spreading rapidly nationwide and infiltrating other animal populations.
Brown County is likely [seeing a return](https://fox11online.com/newsletter-daily/howard-officials-report-bird-flu-resurgence-after-dozens-of-dead-geese-found-in-quarry-duck-creek-quarry-avian-flu-wisconsin-dnr) of the bird flu, after [more than a dozen geese were found dead](https://fox11online.com/newsletter-daily/howard-officials-report-bird-flu-resurgence-after-dozens-of-dead-geese-found-in-quarry-duck-creek-quarry-avian-flu-wisconsin-dnr) in Howard in the last 10 days -- some of which still remain on the partially-frozen Duck Creek Quarry as of Thursday afternoon.
â€œFrom what we've found, they're showing the similar signs -- the loss of head and neck control. The ones we've picked up that have passed away did have the single cataract. I would say very close that it is bird flu, preliminarily. We're not going to know for sure until the lab results come back," said Matt Atkinson, Howard's animal control officer.
Bay Beach Wildlife Sanctuary is [adjusting to protect their captive bird population](https://fox11online.com/news/local/bay-beach-wildlife-sanctuary-restricts-trail-access-ends-corn-sales-amid-bird-flu-concern-avian-raptor-trail-observation-building-waterfowl-patients-wisconsin-dnr) and avoid potential spread. On social media, the organization said:
Due to the recent suspected illnesses in wild waterfowl, Bay Beach Wildlife Sanctuary has decided to stop selling corn and allowing public to walk around our Raptor Trail until further notice.
The post goes on to say that for now, the rehab center will not be accepting any waterfowl patients, and to contact the DNR Wildlife Hotline if you have concerns about wild geese or ducks.
So for now, the ducks and geese at the Bay Beach Wildlife Sanctuary will have to look elsewhere for some extra food.
If you find a duck or goose that appears injured or sick -- don't touch it. Call the Wisconsin DNR hotline at (608) 267-0866.
